snippet.title: Blogger encourages women to stop focusing on their flaws
snippet.content:
Watch This 54-Year-Old's Relentless Workout Routine. Credit - Brian Kahrs via Storyful 1:11
Through a lifetime of intense training and a perfectly balanced diet, Brian has developed what some may call a superhuman body. Under the supervision of his coach, Al Rosen, the 54-year-old has created an intense daily workout routine in order to maintain his fitness. Brian believes that "age doesn't matter, you can always be the toughest person in Walmart". Credit: Brian Kahrs via Storyful

Emma GrittThe Sun

A BLOGGER has begged her followers to see themselves as others would - rather than just focusing on 'faults'. Louise Aubrey, who posts on Instagram under the moniker , shared two identical photos of herself wearing a bikini.
on
She then pointed out what others see - and what she does, reports . The results were thought-provoking, with Parisian student Louise's annotations highlighting just how cruel women can be to themselves. She wrote: "I am guilty. I am here to always be completely honest, because I feel social medias (sic) need more of it. "As much as I preach self love and truly made some progress accepting myself, there is something I really struggle with: pictures. "Whenever I see a picture of me, the first things which catches my eyes are my FLAWS. I always see what is wrong. "I really do not look at people's flaws first when I look at a picture of someone else. On the contrary, I tend to focus on their assets.
on
"We really need to learn not to be so harsh on ourselves. It is not healthy. I am going to work on it, and I hope you will too."
Louise noted that strangers would see her "big smile, long legs and strong butt", but she saw a "big nose, back fat and cellulite". Speaking more about the image to , she explained that there are a lot of reasons why people feel bad about themselves. She said: "Self-criticism comes from several causes. "The society we've evolved in overemphasises our physical appearances.
on
"The influence of role models, the use of photo editing; it puts a great pressure on our shoulders and nourishes the feeling of not being worthy enough." Louise, who blogs about fitness and healthy eating, has also demonstrated the difference between good and bad camera angles - and the difference good posture can make.
